primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Socially Engaged Buddhism is developing in response to social and political struggles, in the context of global conversations on human rights, equity and social progress. Explores roots of Engaged Buddhism in countries such as Vietnam, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and India, and its transformation into a global movement. We study engaged initiatives including Buddhist environmental activism, Buddhist prison ministries, and Buddhist protest movements, along with research on the application of Buddhist teachings in the sectors of healthcare, education, business and the criminal justice system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Socially Engaged Buddhism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online at the scheduled class time. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365 and/or Zoom. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Describes the psychology inherent within the original teachings of Buddhism. Primary focus is on the understanding of the causes of suffering and happiness, the nature of cognition and emotion, characteristics of the self/ego, personality transformation, the role of the unconscious, and mindfulness meditation. Includes an option for Community Engaged Learning experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhist Psychology

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the current interest in incorporating mindfulness into biomedical mental health interventions. Examines the concept of mindfulness closely to see how mindfulness is implicitly a component of biomedical psychological theories and interventions may also enrich those interventions, contributing novel Asian-derived perspectives to biomedical theory and practice. Emphasis is placed on the innovative contributions of Asian-derived aspects of mindfulness to better understand the structure of the embodied mind in the context of biomedical psychological intervention.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mindfulness-Informed Interventions for Mental Health

courses.name: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides a conceptual and practical exploration of several ancient wisdom traditions. Buddhist approaches to self-actualization and wisdom will be compared to several other wisdom traditions (e.g. Mesopotamia, classical Greece, Christianity, Renaissance, etc.) Includes guided experiential exercises for each of the wisdom traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor
Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: In recent years, the effects of meditation on the body have been widely researched. There is an increasing body of evidence that mindfulness meditation can affect brain activity, brain structure, neurochemistry and other psychobiological processes (e.g. blood pressure, cardiac function). This course will examine the research in this emerging field.
cmCourseInfo.title: Meditation and the Body

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Mindfulness meditation is a systematic investigation of subjective experience. Classic and modern descriptions of mindfulness and the recent scientific literature are surveyed. In addition to exploring a variety of meditative practices in the class, students are also required to maintain an ongoing meditation practice outside of class time over the duration of the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exploring Mindful Awareness
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW338H1, NEW432H1 (Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Cultivating Consciousness), offered in Fall 2012, Fall 2013, Fall 2014, Summer 2015, and Winter 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary study of theories of mind, consciousness, and the self, placing Buddhist traditions in dialogue with scientific theories of the mind in psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mind, Consciousness and the Self

courses.name: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores teachings and principles in Buddhist canonical sources and considers their application to a wide range of social, political, and environmental crises we are facing today, including climate justice, systemic racism, burnout and mental health. We explore how Buddhist teachings are applied and adapted across different sectors of society including healthcare, education and business.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW214Y1/ NEW336H1 (Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues), offered in Winter 2020 or Winter 2021/ BPM336H1 (Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues), offered in Winter 2022

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor
Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An exponential increase of scientific research on aspects of Buddhist theories of mind and mindfulness meditation has contributed to the growing popularity of mindfulness across the sectors of healthcare, education and business. Examines the theoretical and empirical basis of mindfulness-based interventions and applications in healthcare settings and beyond. Critically addresses the roots of mindfulness, current models and adaptations, relevant applications, interventions and outcomes. Conceptual, methodological, statistical, and interpretive limitations of the scientific literature will be discussed. Basic research methodology will be reviewed throughout the course, with the aim to develop research skillsets that can be applied beyond this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mindfulness Meditation: Science and Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A statistics course (e.g. PSY201H1, SOC202H1, STA220H1)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes
